IRS990.MissionDesc: Hendricks Community Hospital Assn & Retirement Home strives to provide the highest quality health and residential care in a Christian environment.
IRS990.Desc: Hendricks Community Hospital, a 24-bed hospital, 58-bed long-term care facility, 16-unit senior rental housing facility, and home health agency promotes health of the community by providing a variety of health care services. The facility had 74 acute, 49 swing bed, 10 transitional bed and 22 long-term care facility admissions for the year ended June 30, 2018; 470 visits to the Emergency Room; and 140 surgical cases (including ambulatory). The Hospital provides care to patients who meet certain criteria under its charity care policy without charge or at amounts less than established rates. Continued on Schedule O.Because the Hospital does not pursue collection of amounts determined to qualify as charity care, they are not reported as patient and resident service revenue. The amount of charges foregone for services provided under the Hospital's charity care policy were approximately $15,000 for the year ended June 30, 2018. The estimated cost of providing these services was $12,000 for the year ended June 30, 2018, based on average ratio of cost to gross charges.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The assets of Hendricks Hospital Auxiliary are held by Hendricks Community Hospital Association. The Auxiliary uses the EIN of the Hospital, therefore the activity is reported on Form 990 of the Hospital. The ending balance for the Auxiliary was $93,136. In addition, the Hospital holds funds on behalf of its residents. The amount held at the end of the year for residents was $5,174.
The organization holds security deposits.

The Association is organized as a Minnesota not-for-profit corporation and has been recognized by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) as exempt from federal income taxes under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). The Association is annually required to file a Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax (Form 990) with the IRS. In addition, the Association is subject to income tax on any net income that is derived from business activities that are unrelated to its exempt purpose. The Association has determined it is not subject to unrelated business income tax and has not filed an Exempt Organization Business Income Tax Return (Form 990T) with the IRS. The Association believes it has appropriate support for any tax positions taken affecting its annual filing requirements, and, as such, does not have any uncertain tax positions that are material to the consolidated financial statements. The Association would recognize future accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits and liabilities in income tax expense, if such interest and penalties are incurred.

Bad debt expense reported in revenue on financial statements -62,486. Expenses reported in contributions on financial statements -5,239. Auxiliary contributions to Hospital not reported on Form 990 37,000.
Auxiliary revenue not included in financial statements 41,953. Auxiliary Thrift shop expenses reported in revenue on Form 990 -1,373.

Auxiliary expenses not included in financial statements 2,576. Bad debt expense reported in revenue on financial statements 62,486. Expenses reported as contributions on financial statements 5,239. Resident fund expenses not included in financial statements 408.

SupplementalInformationGrp.ExplanationTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 5: Four focus groups were formulated to provide input in completion of the current Community Health Needs Assessment. Participants in those groups included business/community leaders, health care providers (including public health), seniors and young parents. A total of 24 individuals were interviewed.

Part V, Section B, Line 11: Members of the hospital board and facility leadership team have met to identify the top community health needs and conduct strategic planning. The team has rated the community health needs based on the ability of the facility to respond to the needs of the community. Team members continue to strategize on how best to address the objectives and needs as presented. The facility leadership teams are meeting on an on-going basis to move the strategies forward.Of the community health needs identified, the hospital will address: Awareness of Services; Staff Recognition, Affordable Care; Wellness Promotion, and Mental Health Needs.The Hospital will not address Drug and Alcohol Abuse since it is not feasible with current resources.The following updates took place during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2018:1. Expanding Market Strategiesa. Social media options implemented - utilizing facebook, community digital sign and facility website. Lung cancer screenings are promoted in news media.2. Foster Internal Culture of Appreciation & Developmenta. In addition to new employee orientation, in-house new staff group training is taking place on a monthly basis, as well as 30/60/90 day check-ins with new hires.b. Scholarship availabilities promoted.c. Encourage participation in Medi-Sota workshops and webinars3. Community Wellnessa. Dietary department is providing healthy meal choicesb. Discounted rate for staff to utilize community exercise center4. Mental Health Servicesa. Continued study is taking place for psychiatric tele-health servicesa. Law enforcement and area facility representatives have held meetings to study avenues of improving availability of mental health services.5. Financial Stewardshipa. Departmental year-to-date budgets are being distributed quarterly.b. Volunteer coordinator is regularly promoting utilization of volunteers

Part V, Section B, Line 13h: Discounted care eligibility is determined by utilizing asset and ability to pay information obtained from the patient or responsible party. Discounted care portion of the account is determined based on the patient's financial status and ability to pay the account.

Part V, Section B, Line 16j: Summaries of the financial assistance policy are posted in the hospital/clinic facilities, as well as waiting rooms and admission area. Billing statements to potentially eligible clients also include summary and contact information for obtaining the appropriate application.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Discounted care eligibility is determined by utilizing asset and ability to pay information obtained from the patient or responsible party. Discounted care portion of the account is determined based on the patient's financial status and ability to pay the account.

Charity care is based on an overall cost to charge ratio addressing all patient segments. Community health improvement services, health professions education, and cash and in-kind contributions for community benefit expenses are based on actual expenses recorded to the general ledger. Subsidized health services are reported according to costs allocated to the relevant cost centers on the Medicare Cost Report.
The amount of bad debt expense removed from the denominator of the calculation was $62,486.

Many leaders and staff of the hospital are involved with local community groups like Kiwanis and other community clubs. Their involvement provides them the opportunity to get involved in speaking to community members on health topics and encouraging community involvement in other health activities, like blood drives. Funds were used to host an appreciation dinner and for physician recruitment.

Bad debt expense is reported net of discounts and contractual allowances. A payment on an account previously written off reduces the bad debt expense in the current year. Bad debt expense on line 2 is reported at charges as presented on the financial statements.

Bad debt expense is determined based on a patient's payment history as well as current known financial status. Such expense is determined by a patient's non-payment status and non-probability of payment. Because of the nature of these accounts, it is found that at least 50% of these accounts would fall into the charity care status.
The footnote to the organization's financial statements that describes bad debt expense is located on page 7 of the attached financial statements.

The Hospital provides services to Medicare patients because access to healthcare and patient's health is important to the Hospital. Total revenue received from Medicare is the gross reimbursement plus settlement. Both total revenue received from Medicare and the Medicare allowable costs are reported from the Medicare Cost Report. The Medicare Cost Report is completed based on the rules and regulations set forth by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

Patients are classified in the poverty level utilizing the Federal poverty guidelines as also referenced in our facility collection policy. The guidelines are referenced when a patient fails to complete payment of his/her account in a timely manner. Prior to being turned over to a collection agency, a patient is offered 120 days to complete a charity care application, thereby allowing staff time to determine the income level of the patient and their qualification as a poverty level individual. If they so chose to not complete an application, their account would be referred to a collection agency. The Hospital allows an additional 120 days for a patient to apply for financial assistance. If the patient is determined to be eligible for financial assistance collection activities will cease.

We are consistently addressing the additional service needs as voiced through the physicians who serve our clientele, as well as the clientele themselves.The community health needs assessment and implementation strategy have been completed and are available on our website at www.hendrickshosp.org.

Patient's insurance information is obtained upon admission, and those patients not having current third party coverage are informed of the ability to apply for medical assistance funding or visit with our business office staff and social service staff regarding alternative payments and the charity care options. In addition, the patient statements provide information related to contacting our business office personnel to complete alternative payment arrangements, i.e. charity care, Medicaid or planned payment schedule. Patients are offered an option of setting an appointment to meet with staff to complete such arrangements. These procedures are also detailed in our financial assistance/charity care policy.

Hendricks Community Hospital serves a primarily rural population within a 30-mile radius of the community of Hendricks. The facility is located in Lincoln County, Minnesota, which is slated as one of the highest elderly population counties in the State. The average median income for the county is $49,438 with the highest portion of the population being over 65 years of age. However, because of the high elderly population, many of those constituents are insured through federal government programs and do not necessarily relate to increased Medicaid levels. There is one other acute care facility in the county approximately 30 miles away. Our facility is also located within one-mile of the South Dakota border, and a good margin of population served is located in that state. During the fiscal year ending 6/30/18, it was noted approximately 22% of our patients were insured through Medical Assistance programs, and approximately 11% were un-insured.

The nine members of the association's Board of Directors represent varying communities within the 30-mile service area. The board members provide valuable input of the health care needs of the area served.Medical staff privileges are extended to qualified physicians within the service area as well as outlying areas to provide the optimum level of care for our constituents. These privileges are granted to several specialty physicians to eliminate the need for additional travel for our patients.The Association continually allocates funds to the improvement of the facilities and equipment utilized to provide the optimum service to our patients. Surplus funds are also provided to enhance community services with donations to service organizations who offer additional health-enhancing services to the residents of the area. The rural health clinics in the Hendricks community and neighboring Ivanhoe community provide for improved community access. Particularily in the Ivanhoe community it has proved beneficial to be able to offer services in their primary dwelling location.Emergency room services are available 24/7, and are offered regardless of payment source or ability to pay.The facility also participates in the Minnesota SAGE and South Dakota All Women County programs which offer women yearly physical exams, including mammograms and pap smears at no cost to the patient.Facility staff is involved in community economic planning groups as well as community service organizations.Many area residents are involved as volunteers within our organization and participate on a daily basis enhancing the lives of the residents and patients in our facility.

The City of Hendricks received a $20,000 grant to be used for city street repairs due to damage from the construction equipment utilizing the streets during the Hospital's construction project. Other grants and assistance are given on an as needed basis with the board approval as part of the financial statement process. Grants are given for health and wellness and community improvements in the area as the administration and board deem appropriate.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 1
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Executive Committee is composed of the President, Vice-President, Secretary and Treasurer of the governing board. Responsibilities include: A. General management and control of the affairs of the corporation. In addition to formal meetings, the committee has informal conferences about corporation activities. B. Shall have the power to transact all regular business of the hospital during the interim between the meetings of the Board of Directors provided any action taken shall not conflict with the policies and expressed wishes of the Board of Directors, and that it shall refer all matters of major importance to the Board of Directors. C. It shall cause to be prepared and submit to the Board of Directors at its last meeting before the end of the fiscal year, a budget showing the expected receipts and income and expense for the ensuing year. It shall be the further duty of the Executive Committee to examine the monthly financial reports and to require an explanation from the Administrator for any material variation from the budget. D. The Executive Committee shall evaluate in April annually or as deemed necessary, the Chief Executive Officer's performance and recommend his/her remuneration to the full Board of Directors. This committee shall meet as necessary.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Matt Amundson and George Jorgensen have a business relationship. Matt Amundson and Vince Robinson have a business relationship.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: There is one class of membership. Membership is open to any natural person who is of legal voting age and a voting resident within the organization's primary service area.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each member receives one vote.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The return is reviewed by the Business Office Manager and CEO, then by the Board of Directors before it is filed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The policy covers all officers, directors, and key employees. A conflict of interest form is signed upon orientation to the Board of Directors. The form is reviewed by the CEO and any potential conflicts are reviewed with the Board of Directors. If a conflict exists, the person with the conflict is restricted from voting on related matters. Conflict of interest forms are completed annually by board of directors and key employees. These are reviewed by the HR director, and compliance report submitted to the governing board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Executive Committee reviews the CEO's compensation annually and compares to similar positions at other hospitals of similar size and geographic location. The Board of Directors reviews and approves the recommendations of the Executive Committee. This process was last evaluated in 2016. The officers of the board receive a stipend for attending meetings. The fee structure is based on meetings attended. This compensation process is determined by board members and the fee schedule is discussed by the board annually.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Organization makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available to the public upon request.
